title: What happened to the millions of French troops that surrendered at the beginning of WW2? - Quora

response.answer_text: “What happened to the millions of French troops that surrendered at the beginning of WW2?” About 1.8 millions soldiers were captured.  it says “Souvenir Morose” (Sad memory) on the apron 330 000 of them were sent back to France in 1940–1941, for medical reasons. Many of them spent the remainder of the war in POW camps, like my paternal grandfather (pictured on these photos). They were used for various work, such as working the German farms while German soldiers were busy elsewhere. Some others stayed in Germany to work as civilians in factories. Several thousands colonial soldiers (Moroccans, Senegalese,…) were murdered. Here are a few pictures from my private collection. (Reproduction forbidden without my consent). My grandfather was in a POW camp in the region of Nuremberg, Stalag XIII A (Sulzbach-Rosenberg, Oberpfalz)  May 17 1942. Notice the KG, meaning Kriegsgefangener (Prisoner of War)  Taking care of cows in a German farm (June 2nd 1943)  They were trying to entertain themselves, with men dressed as women. Between 1940 to 1945, 51 000 of them died.
